intro: Scolopia closiana, commonly known as the scarlet false shamrock, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant produces striking red, velvety flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are trifoliate, consisting of three heart-shaped leaflets, giving it a distinctive appearance. Scolopia closiana thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland areas and along stream banks.
